awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Conference: A Workshop to Explore Data Science in Oceanography
awd_abstract_narration:
Computational and data science skills have become essential in making scientific discoveries, especially in fields where the integration of diverse sources of observational and modeled data is required to understand the mechanisms and functions of complex systems, such as the Earth’s ocean. However, conventional ocean sciences education focuses predominantly on domain-specific knowledge and often falls short in explicitly incorporating these operational skills into the curriculum. The PIs will plan and host several workshops, a virtual workshop in 2020 and two in-person workshops in 2021, that aim to address this urgent need by combining immersive tutorials on state-of-the-art data science methodologies, peer-learning, and on-site collaborative hack project work in a 5-day intensive workshop. This is a domain-specific adaptation of the “hackweek” model, which has emerged in the computational data science community as a powerful model for educating new users, sharing technical expertise, and building an inclusive and cohesive community. The focus of the workshops is the use of ocean data, and specifically the use of data from the NSF-funded Ocean Observatories Initiative. 

The workshops, called "OceanHackWeek2020-2021", provide an avenue for expediting the adoption of data science methodologies and computational tools for data-intensive research in the ocean sciences community. These skills are indispensable for modern-day oceanographers to tackle complex scientific questions by harnessing the data revolution. OceanHackWeek differs from traditional academic conferences and one-off hackathons by its immersive curriculum, collaborative learning environment, and a set of carefully crafted participant selection criteria that helps promote diversity and inclusivity. These designs help spur collaborative interdisciplinary ideas and help promote best data science practices in ocean sciences. OceanHackWeek focuses not only on promoting data science literacy but also on building an inclusive and cohesive community of oceanographers for learning and sharing. The organizers encourage and empower participants to bring the skills gained and the sense of community formed during the hackweek back to their own labs and institutions. Beyond the intensive in-person workshop, OceanHackWeek tutorials will be maintained as persistent open online resources to allow anyone to partake and self-learn. By facilitating and catalyzing the growth and change of individuals through grassroot efforts that promote and embrace a diverse community, OceanHackWeek drives cultural change in the field of oceanography.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Computational and data science skills have become essential for enabling scientific discoveries, especially in fields such as ocean science where the integration of diverse sources of observational and modeled data is required to understand the mechanisms and functions of complex systems. For example, biological, chemical and physical in-situ measurements from ships and autonomous vehicles can be combined with remote-sensing observations from satellites to corroborate and refine predictions from ocean circulation and ecosystem models.

In ocean science, the challenges posed by such heterogeneous data are compounded by the highly interdisciplinary nature of the field, spanning physics, biology, chemistry, geology and other disciplines. A community of scientists conversant with modern data science skills and analytical approaches across all subdomains of ocean sciences is crucial for making significant advances in understanding complex problems, such as the cascading effects of climate change on marine ecosystems.

The "hackweek" model has emerged within the data science community as a powerful model for educating new users, sharing technical expertise and building an inclusive and cohesive user community at the intersection of data science and a particular scientific field. These week-long events provide unique opportunities for learning and sharing data science skills when academic courses focused on that intersection are not widely available across institutions. Specifically, conventional ocean science education has focused predominantly on domain-specific knowledge and often falls short in explicitly incorporating computational and data science skills into the curriculum. In contrast, hackweeks are intensive and interactive, facilitated by a combination of three core components: immersive tutorials on state-of-the-art methodology, peer-learning, and project work in a collaborative environment. These needs in the ocean community motivated the organization of the first annual OceanHackWeek (OHW) events that took place at the University of Washington in 2018 and 2019.

Funding from this grant supported the expansion and continued growth of OHW from 2020 to 2022. During this time, the leadership team refined the goals of OHW to focus on 1) promoting data and software proficiency in the ocean sciences community, and 2) facilitating inclusive community building. We believe the diversity of experience and identity of OHW participants are key to cultivate an inclusive, open and sharing culture that is conducive to data-intensive research, and strived to achieve these goals by providing oceanographers with computational and data science skills to integrate and analyze diverse sources of data and models and at the same time connecting oceanographers across disciplines, career stages and trajectories.

In particular, this funding support enabled a successful pivot of the OHW format from traditional in-person workshops to a virtual event in 2020 under the COVID19 global pandemic, while retaining an emphasis on the learning experiences of individual participants together with other participants. This transformation was accompanied by a more diverse leadership team comprised of members from multiple organizations in the US and Australia, broader inclusion of materials from different ocean science subdomains and the R programming language in tutorial materials and projects, and wider engagement of participants from groups underrepresented in oceanography and international participants through a refined participant selection process.  These advancements were retained in the 2021 and 2022 hybrid events with different facilitating structures between in-person and virtual components.

From 2020 to 2022, OHW engaged 220 virtual and in-person participants from academic institutions, government agencies, and other organizations in the US and more than 25 countries around the world. In addition, some event components in 2022 were carried out in Portuguese and Spanish. The events were supported by more than 70 instructors, project mentors, helpers and primary organizers, including those in the OHW leadership team, all from the international ocean sciences and related data science communities. The in-person components of hybrid events took place at four locations in the US, one in Australia and two in South America. Across these events, 32 tutorials were delivered and all remain openly available on our website (https://oceanhackweek.org). Participants collaboratively developed 39 projects in all ocean science subdomains based on ideas proposed by participants themselves or suggestions by project mentors. These projects spanned from method development, data analysis, workflow construction, to software development, and used data from diverse sources including the NSF Ocean Observatories Initiative, satellites and models.

Over the course of three years, the OHW leadership team created a governing structure that includes a Steering Committee that oversees future development of the OHW organization and events. With core members each with substantial experience organizing and facilitating diverse workshops and hackweek events, OHW is well positioned to continue its impact on data science in oceanography as a community-wide effort.
